greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of partitions of {1,..,n} into lists with an odd number of lists of size 1, where a list means an ordered subset, cf. A000262.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..444
formula: E.g.f.: sinh(x)*exp(x^2/(1-x)). More generally, e.g.f. for number of partitions of {1, 2, ...n} into lists with an odd number of lists of size k is sinh(x^k)*exp(x/(1-x)-x^k).
E.g.f.: sinh(x)*exp(x^2/(1-x))=1/2*Q(0);   Q(k)=1-((2x-1)^k)/( 1-x/(x-((2x-1)^k)*(k+1)*(1-x)/Q(k+1)));  (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Nov 17 2011
maple: b:= proc(n, t) option remember; `if`(n=0, t, add(b(n-j,
mathematica: b[n_, t_] := b[n, t] = If[n==0, t, Sum[b[n-j, If[j==1, 1-t, t]]*Binomial[ n-1, j-1]*j!, {j, 1, n}]]; a[n_] := b[n, 0]; Table[a[n], {n, 0, 30}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Feb 03 2017, after _Alois P. Heinz_ *)
program: from sympy import binomial, factorial as f
def b(n, t): return t if n==0 else sum([b(n - j, (1 - t if j==1 else t))*binomial(n - 1, j - 1)*f(j) for j in range(1, n + 1)])
print([a(n) for n in range(51)]) # _Indranil Ghosh_, Aug 10 2017
results.author: _Vladeta Jovovic_, Nov 19 2005; corrected Jun 06 2006
ext: a(0)=0 prepended by _Alois P. Heinz_, May 10 2016
